question: Question_01_(g)
statement:
Find the interval(s) on which

\[\displaystyle f(x) = x^2 - \ln(x)\]

is increasing.
sols:
The given function is increasing where its first derivative is positive.
Taking the derivative yields

\[\displaystyle f'(x) = 2x - 1/x\]

We must now solve the inequality for \emph{x} yields the interval where
$f$ is increasing. We will only be interested in positive values of
\emph{x}, as negative values of \emph{x} are not in the domain of the
given function (because of the natural logarithm). Therefore,

\begin{align*}
0 &< 2x - 1/x , \quad x > 0\\
1/x &< 2x \\
1 & < 2x^2 \\
\frac{1}{2} &< x^2 \\
\end{align*} Therefore, we have

\[x > + \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\]

The negative solution was ruled out because of the requirement that
\emph{x} be a positive number.

The interval on which $f$ is increasing is

\[(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}, \infty)\]
hints: A function is increasing when its slope is positive.
